pullRequest.body:
Hoeffding and Azuma-Hoeffding inequalities for sub-Gaussian random variables.

---

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ HasSubgaussianMGF_add_of_HasCondSubgaussianMGF`
`+ HasSubgaussianMGF_sum_of_HasCondSubgaussianMGF`
`+ add_comp`
`+ add_compProd`
`+ add_of_indepFun`
`+ integrable_exp_add_compProd`
`+ measure_sum_ge_le_of_HasCondSubgaussianMGF`
`+ measure_sum_ge_le_of_iIndepFun`
`+ measure_sum_range_ge_le_of_iIndepFun`
`+ prodMkLeft_compProd`
`+ sum_of_iIndepFun`
`+ trim`
`+ zero_kernel`
`+ zero_measure`
`++ of_map`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:

```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#22623~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
That's very nice, thanks!

```suggestion
    rw [map_apply _ hY, mgf_map hY.aemeasurable]
    convert (h_int t).1
    rw [map_apply _ hY]
```
You should be able to prove this for an arbitrary random variable `Y`instead of `id` no? Also the forward direction is given by `of_map` directly.

```suggestion
    simpa using h.integrable_exp_mul
```

```suggestion
    have h2 := h.mgf_le
    rw [â† Measure.snd_compProd, Measure.snd] at h2
    exact ae_of_ae_map (by fun_prop) h2
```
I don't think you need to assume s-finiteness here?

```suggestion
    rwa [ENNReal.coe_ofNat, Measure.comp_compProd_comm, Measure.snd,
      memLp_map_measure_iff h.1 measurable_snd.aemeasurable] at h
```
I'm guessing this could also be generalized by replacing `id` by an arbitrary random variable `Y`, and golfed using `of_map` below.

The generalization beyond `id` needs some measurability assumption. I did not figure out quickly which one exactly and I gave up (it might not be that hard, I did not try much). With the `id` result I only wanted to highlight that sub-Gaussian is a property of the law of a random variable, not of other properties of the random variable. Since it's not actually used anywhere else and I don't want to spend time on the general version now, I deleted it.
Just throwing an idea here, did not think about it carefully: does there exist a similar statement for the `Kernel.HasSubgaussianMGF` case? Which might imply this one and also imply `add_compProd`.

There exists a similar statement for the kernel case, but it will require several hundred lines of changes in the Mathlib.Probability.Integration file to generalize to kernels so I'd rather leave it for later.

I don't see how it could also imply `add_compProd` though. If we have a sequence of measurable spaces linked by kernels, the `IndepFun` result is about adding random variables from the same measurable space, while `add_compProd` is about adding random variables from different spaces along that sequence. I see it as horizontal vs vertical properties.

My idea was that in `add_compProd` you could see the variables as independent variables on the product of all the measurable spaces by composing them with projections. But indeed if it's too heavy no need to deal with it right now.

You're right. It is actually a general truth that instead of using kernels we could (almost?) always put everything on a common space and use conditional properties instead, here conditional independence.
Using kernels in many parts of the library is more of a choice than a necessity. I find that the rigidity of kernels, with their different spaces for domain and codomain, has a lot of benefits when developing the theory. You don't have to ask yourself if something should be measurable with respect to a sigma-algebra or another, since each space has only one sigma-algebra. More generally, if you can write something, it's the thing that makes sense (there is usually only a single way to compose kernels to get a target kernel type, etc.).

With the point of view I have of kernels as a convenient way to write about conditional stuff, doing the opposite and transporting everything to one space to then come back to the kernel setting does not make much sense.

That's a good point. The main drawback I see with this is that it makes much more use of kernels than what we are used to in paper maths (at least that I am), but I also think that it is better for the purpose of formalization.

```suggestion
    simp_rw [â† Finset.sum_apply, Finset.sum_insert his, Pi.add_apply, Finset.sum_apply]
```

```suggestion
  simpa [â† mul_assoc] using h
```

```suggestion
    have h_eq : X + Y = (fun p â†¦ X p.1 + Y p.2) âˆ˜ (fun Ï‰ â†¦ (id Ï‰, id Ï‰)) := rfl

```suggestion
* `measure_sum_ge_le_of_iIndepFun`: Hoeffding's inequality for sums of independent sub-Gaussian
```

```suggestion
  Â· simp [exp_nonneg]
```

I have two remarks here, I hope I am not talking non sense. First, if `Y i` is both `â„± i`-measurable and conditionally sub-Gaussian with respect to `â„± i`, it means that for any `t`, for almost every `Ï‰`, $\exp(tY_i(\omega)) \le \exp(ct^2/2)$ which means that if `t>0` $Y_i(\omega) \le ct/2$, and taking `t` rational we get that `Y i` is almost surely nonpositive, and by symmetry almost surely equal to `0`. So I'm guessing this is not the good hypothesis, I would say you want conditional sub-Gaussianity with respect to `â„± (i-1)` (I checked and the proof still works).
Second, you say `Y` is a martingale, with these hypotheses it's true because it is zero, but if you change the hypothesis to what I wrote above you get that the sum of the `Y i`s is a martingale rather than `Y`.

Thank you for noticing the off-by-one error! Results about the constant zero process are not very interesting.
And yes, the martingale is the sum.
I switched to `i - 1` for the sub-Gaussian assumption. It still forces `Y 0` to be 0 for the reason you described.
I changed the hypotheses to avoid `Y 0 = 0`.

Maybe
```lean
âˆ€ i, HasCondSubgaussianMGF (â„± i) (â„±.le i) (Y (i + 1)) (cY (i + 1)) Î¼
```
is a nicer spelling, what do you think?

You shouldn't need the assumption on mu, as you can deduce it's a probability measure from `h_indep`, with
```
  have : IsProbabilityMeasure Î¼ := h_indep.isProbabilityMeasure
```
Same thing below.
This shouldn't stop the PR, but I don't see how measurability can be relevant since you already have ae measurability from `h_subG`.

pullRequest.title: feat(Probability): Azuma-Hoeffding inequality for sub-Gaussian random variables
